descr: of Yield
The yaffle.
Went; walked; proceeded.
of Yodle
of Yodle
of Yodle
of Yodle
Alt. of Yodle
To sing in a manner common among the Swiss and Tyrolese mountaineers, by suddenly changing from the head voice, or falsetto, to the chest voice, and the contrary; to warble.
Alt. of Yodle
A song sung by yodeling, as by the Swiss mountaineers.
One who yodels.

A species of asceticism among the Hindoos, which consists in a complete abstraction from all worldly objects, by which the votary expects to obtain union with the universal spirit, and to acquire superhuman faculties.
A follower of the yoga philosophy; an ascetic.
A cry of encouragement to foxhounds.
The European yellow-hammer.
A measure of distance, varying from four to ten miles, but usually about five.
A bar or frame of wood by which two oxen are joined at the heads or necks for working together.
A frame or piece resembling a yoke, as in use or shape.
A frame of wood fitted to a person\'s shoulders for carrying pails, etc., suspended on each side; as, a milkmaid\'s yoke.
A frame worn on the neck of an animal, as a cow, a pig, a goose, to prevent passage through a fence.
A frame or convex piece by which a bell is hung for ringing it.  See Illust. of Bell.
A crosspiece upon the head of a boat\'s rudder.  To its ends lines are attached which lead forward so that the boat can be steered from amidships.
A bent crosspiece connecting two other parts.
A tie securing two timbers together, not used for part of a regular truss, but serving a temporary purpose, as to provide against unusual strain.
A band shaped to fit the shoulders or the hips, and joined to the upper full edge of the waist or the skirt.
Fig.: That which connects or binds; a chain; a link; a bond connection.
A mark of servitude; hence, servitude; slavery; bondage; service.
Two animals yoked together; a couple; a pair that work together.
The quantity of land plowed in a day by a yoke of oxen.
A portion of the working day; as, to work two yokes, that is, to work both portions of the day, or morning and afternoon.
of Yoke
of Yoke
To put a yoke on; to join in or with a yoke; as, to yoke oxen, or pair of oxen.
To couple; to join with another.
To enslave; to bring into bondage; to restrain; to confine.
To be joined or associated; to be intimately connected; to consort closely; to mate.
See Rokeage.
An associate or companion in, or as in; a mate; a fellow; especially, a partner in marriage.
A country bumpkin.
A small farm; -- so called as requiring but one yoke of oxen to till it.
Same as Yokefellow.
Having two toes in front and two behind, as the trogons and woodpeckers.
Yielded.
Yielded.
The yellow part of an egg; the vitellus.
An oily secretion which naturally covers the wool of sheep.
To yell.
At a distance, but within view; yonder.
Yonder.
A local name in parts of the Mississippi Valley for the American lotus (Nelumbo lutea).
Furious; mad; angry; fierce.
Yonder.
At a distance, but within view.
Being at a distance within view, or conceived of as within view; that or those there; yon.
The symbol under which Sakti, or the personification of the female power in nature, is worshiped.  Cf. Lingam.
A young fellow; a younker.
In time long past; in old time; long since.
A tice.
A county in the north of England.
The one of the three printed uses of England which was followed in the north. It was based on the Sarum use.  See Use, n., 6.
To unite closely.
To pour water on; to soak in, or mix with, water.
The pronoun of the second person, in the nominative, dative, and objective case, indicating the person or persons addressed.  See the Note under Ye.
To yell; to yowl.
Not long born; still in the first part of life; not yet arrived at adolescence, maturity, or age; not old; juvenile; -- said of animals; as, a young child; a young man; a young fawn.
Being in the first part, pr period, of growth; as, a young plant; a young tree.
Having little experience; inexperienced; unpracticed; ignorant; weak.
The offspring of animals, either a single animal or offspring collectively.
One who is younger; an inferior in age; a junior.
Somewhat young.
A young person; a youth; also, any animal in its early life.
Young; youthful.
Like a young person or thing; young; youthful.
In a young manner; in the period of youth; early in life.
Ignorantly; weakly.
The quality or state of being young.
A young person; a youngling; a lad.
Youth.
Pertaining to, or resembling, youth; youthful.
A young person; a stripling; a yonker.
Same as Yaupon.
The form of the possessive case of the personal pronoun you.
See the Note under Your.
of Yourself

An emphasized or reflexive form of the pronoun of the second person; -- used as a subject commonly with you; as, you yourself shall see it; also, alone in the predicate, either in the nominative or objective case; as, you have injured yourself.
of Youth
of Youth
The quality or state of being young; youthfulness; juvenility.
The part of life that succeeds to childhood; the period of existence preceding maturity or age; the whole early part of life, from childhood, or, sometimes, from infancy, to manhood.
A young person; especially, a young man.
Young persons, collectively.
Not yet mature or aged; young.
Also used figuratively.
Of or pertaining to the early part of life; suitable to early life; as, youthful days; youthful sports.
Fresh; vigorous, as in youth.
The quality or state of being a youth; the period of youth.
Young; youthful.
Youthful.
Young.
The cheetah.
You.
A ewe.
To utter a loud, long, and mournful cry, as a dog; to howl; to yell.
A loud, protracted, and mournful cry, as that of a dog; a howl.
The European yellow-hammer.
See Yex.
